#Text=Be a Respectful Non Jewish Guest at a Jewish Holiday Dinner
#Text=For even the most well-meaning gentiles , the ceremonies surrounding a Jewish holiday dinner can be intimidating .
#Text=Luckily , there 's nothing preventing them from spending the holidays with members of the Jewish faith with tact , respect , and genuine enjoyment .
#Text=Steps
#Text=Feel free to ask your hosts questions about Judaism .

#Text=Also note that your participation in Jewish customs , as led by your hosts , does not obligate you to anything in any way , nor will it nullify or " de-commit " you from your own spiritual path .
#Text=Many non-Jews are open-minded to learning about how Jews live .

#Text=If your friends are Orthodox Jews , do n't expect hugs , kisses , and handshakes from the women if you 're a man , because touch ( even something considered " casual contact " in the non-observant world , such as a handshake ) is a form of intimacy and therefore , reserved for spouses and immediate family only ( children , parents , siblings ) .

column1: #Text=For the same reason , if you are a woman , do not expect hugs , kisses , or handshakes from Orthodox men .
#Text=Dress appropriately .
#Text=If it 's an Orthodox Jewish home , and you 're a woman , wear a modest ( covers elbows , knee-length or longer hemline , no exposed decolletage ) , dressy dress , or blouse and skirt .
#Text=If you 're a man , wear a suit and tie , and you 're likely to receive a kippah ( skullcap ) for your head .
#Text=If it 's NOT an Orthodox home , business casual clothes are likely appropriate .
#Text=If it 's Shabbat , ritual handwashing will be done , and there will be blessings for Shabbat candles , wine , challah ( bread ) , children , and guests .

#Text=Depending on the level of observance , there may be further discussion for you to participate in centered around the biblical narrative for the week ( after a brief description of the narrative is given- comments and opinions welcome ) , and singing .
#Text=Shabbat is the celebration of The Creation and the Jews ' ( and humanity 's ) place in it- completed in 6 days , with G-d resting ( and commanding the Jews also to rest ) on the 7th day .
#Text=A festive meal and drinks are served .
#Text=If it 's Passover , ( the feast of unleavened bread ) matzah is served in place of bread , and no regular flour-containing items will be served .

#Text=Be prepared to spend at least 2 to 4 hours at the dining room table ( you may want to eat a significant snack before you go- the full meal is n't served for an hour or two after your arrival ) , because Passover is the holiday in which the Jews were freed from slavery in Egypt , and the story itself is read from a Haggadah ( Jewish book ) along with prayers and songs .
#Text=Watch what everyone is saying and doing , and do n't talk , eat , and drink until everyone else does .
#Text=A good host will help guide you ( and be reminding everyone else at the table- it 's part of the culture to continuously explain what 's going on and why ) , so relax and enjoy !
#Text=Tips
#Text=If it 's Passover , the only kosher food you can bring must be marked " Kosher for Passover , " or " May be Used for Passover , " or " Kosher for Passover and All Year Round .

#Text= Most Passover foods come out a month or two before the holiday , so read the labels carefully .

column1: #Text=It 's best to buy breads that have Kosher certification without a D [ for dairy ] or from a Kosher bakery if there is one available .
#Text=Warnings
#Text=If you have allergies , tell your Jewish friends and ask about alternatives .
#Text=Quick Summary
